r
. Thowgh the bearer hereof
Capteine Allen
hath
not the place of
Capteine Smithe
, yet was such the
Q. Ma
ties
liking of him to have that place, and to leave
Throgmorton
unpre-
ferred, as if theare had not hapened w
th
in one daie knowledge of a
place voide in
Ostend
by the deathe of one
Capteine Salisburye
, this
Allen should have had the place of Smithe: But he himself was
verie willinge to
s
rve at Ostend in Salisburies place, and so yt
hath fallen owt, that Throgmorton shall have the place of Smithe
in the Companies of the Bandes under
S
r
Francis vere
, and soe
Capteine Allen shall
s
ve, wheare his owne fauncie liketh him
under
S
r
Edward Norris
./ Nowe, wheareas hir Ma
tie
hath
written l
res
at this time to the
States generall
, and to the
Counte
Maurice
, w
ch
this Bringer hath to deliver unto yowe, yowe shall
by the l
re
to yo
r
self understand the Content
of the other two,
w
ch
I will neither reporte nor inlarge for that the Argument
of
thes are but the sequell of my former l
res
written to yowe by hir
Ma
ties
Commaundment: And thowgh the matter be of great importance
and consequence to be speedelie executed, and that w
ch
weare
to be wisshed at this time above anie
s
vice that hath been there
taken in hand this manie yeres, yet I am sorie to be in dowbt
that thes Gouverno
rs
theare will be deafe to the Q request
,
and blinde to their owne proffett: Nevertheles hir Ma
tie
doth the
part of a wise prince, and is solicited verie ernestlie by the
Frenche K.
to have yt prosecuted, and I dowbt not anie thinge
of yo
r
deligence in followinge of this matter to the uttermost: And for
one Argument to the States yowe maie well alledge, that if they
shall not further yt w
th
sped, but that it be broken of, or not followed
effectuallie by their defawlt, hir Ma
tie
will slacke hir affection toward
them, when percase theie shall have most neade of hir, and soe
theie shall de
s
rve yt./
